title: The evolutionary landscape of modern human origins in Africa
descriptions:
This grant proposal, titled "The evolutionary landscape of modern human origins in Africa," aims to investigate the origins of Homo sapiens in Africa approximately 750,000 years ago. The project, named NGIPALAJEM, will focus on the Turkana region and address key research goals such as establishing empirical benchmarks and answering significant questions in the field of human evolution.

The proposed research will involve fieldwork to add specimens to the hominin and large vertebrate fossil record, as well as analyses using inter-site eco-morphological and palaeoproteomic comparative techniques. By examining the role of human predation in shaping modern African faunas and exploring the phenotypic diversity during the Middle Pleistocene, the project seeks to uncover new insights into human evolution within the African evolutionary landscape.

The project will also investigate the impact of climatic changes, such as the End of EMPT period, and the discovery of small Middle Pleistocene Turkana hominins. Utilizing novel morphometric and analytical analysis techniques, the research aims to contribute to a better understanding of human evolution over the last million years.

Overall, the expected outcomes of this project include a deeper understanding of the evolutionary processes that led to the emergence of modern humans in Africa, providing valuable insights into our shared evolutionary history.
